awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Structural and Molecular Mechanisms for Protein Repair in Photosynthetic Membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit 

An essential gap of knowledge in our understanding of photosynthesis is how are plants able to repair photosystem II (PSII), the multi-protein holocomplex which captures light energy.  The objective of this project is to determine the mechanisms by which phosphorylation of PSII alters the thylakoid ultrastructure and enables damaged PSII to be efficiently mobilized from densely packed stacked grana membranes to unstacked thylakoid membranes where it can be repaired for recycling.  The central hypothesis is that PSII phosphorylation triggers a reduction in the grana diameter and separation of adjacent grana membranes on the stromal side thereby facilitating the movement of damaged PSII. Furthermore it is hypothesized that protein phosphorylation increases PSII mobility by triggering the dismantling of the massive holocomplex and by generating electrostatic repulsion.  The rationale of the proposed research is that, once the mechanisms by which protein phosphorylation regulates PSII mobility are known, a better fundamental understanding is available of how plants maintain their photosynthetic machinery for optimal growth and development. The central hypothesis is tested by pursuing two specific aims. Aim 1: Determine phosphorylation-specific changes in the thylakoid ultrastructure by cryo-electron microscopy. Aim 2: Determine the molecular mechanisms revealing how phosphorylation mobilizes PSII in grana. The approach is to measure diffusion data by fluorescence-recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) under various repair conditions and then to compare these results to a FRAP model developed by Monte Carlo-simulations. These approaches will lead to the following expected outcomes. Outcome 1: It is expect that protein-phosphorylation induces a reduction of the grana diameter and that the distance between adjacent grana discs becomes larger. Both ultrastructural changes would facilitate migration of damaged PSII to reach stroma lamellae. Outcome 2: It is expect that phosphorylation accelerates lateral diffusion of damaged PSII by disassembly and electrostatic repulsion. These results are expected to yield an in-depth understanding on the mechanisms of the PSII degradation and also why protein phosphorylation is required for mobilization of damaged grana-hosted PSII.  

Broader Impact 

This research has a broader impact for the understanding of the molecular dynamics in many other biomembranes since the underlying mechanisms are likely to be similar. The societal benefit of the project is that a better understanding of how plants maintain their photosynthetic machinery will help to increase the robustness and efficiency of crop plants for food and biofuel prospects. The project provides training opportunities for two undergraduate students in the exciting field of photosynthesis research.  Efforts will be made to fill these positions by undergraduates from groups under-represented in the sciences.  The project will take advantage of the strong intuitive character of computer movies to generate a computer-based teaching platform. Special topics courses will be developed as a new internet-based course entitled "Molecules in Motion." This course will be accessible to graduate students of Washington State University as well as to others throughout the world

por.por_cntn:
Natural photosynthesis is achieved through biochemistry that occurs within complex microscopic structures called thylakoids. Thylakoids comprise stacks of many membranes, each of which is packed densely with protein molecules that do the business of converting light to chemical energy. In recent years it has been shown that these proteins are sometimes arranged in highly patterned ways, akin to the regular periodic structures of crystals. How this order emerges, how it depends on proteins’ shapes, densities, and interactions, and how it impacts the efficiency and robustness of photosynthesis have, however, been quite unclear. This project combined a variety of scientific tools, from both experimental and theoretical disciplines, to address this knowledge gap. Its products thus advance basic understanding of one of life’s critically important chemical processes. At the same time, they provide some guidance on ways that man-made technologies might achieve similar goals.

The theoretical portion of this project focused on creating mathematical models that capture the essential microscopic features underlying spatial organization of proteins within thylakoid membranes. By necessity, these models discard an enormous collection of molecular details, so that they can be explored thoroughly with current computers in a reasonable amount of time. They specifically resolve proteins’ shapes and sizes, how densely they are packed, and their tendency to cluster and stack together within the thylakoid structure. (An example configuration of this model is shown in the accompanying image.) From this simple set of ingredients, we have shown, emerge patterns very similar to those observed in experiments. Most interestingly, our computer simulations indicate that the appearance of ordered arrays constitutes a true phase transition. Like the freezing of water at 0° C, this transition occurs with striking sharpness and cooperativity. In a biological context, the singular response it implies could well serve to switch robustly between different structural and functional states. We have suggested experiments that could confirm this behavior.

The model we constructed was also used to help interpret data from atomic force microscopy measurements on thylakoids imaged under a variety of conditions. Employing a novel statistical analysis procedure, this work revealed an unexpectedly diverse set of ordering motifs, many of which can be apparent in a single image. These results suggest that the phase transition scenario described above may be even richer still, featuring competition between a number of structures that are nearly equivalent in stability.

Finally, we have used the model to study how protein organization changes in time. As light conditions change, or damaged molecules accumulate, thylakoids are known to reorganize, sometimes in dramatic ways. We simulate this dynamics by suddenly changing model parameters that set the types and strengths of interactions between proteins (representing, e.g., the “tagging” of proteins with a phosphate group). The subsequent rearrangement and redistribution of molecules reveal that local, if not widespread, aggregation of certain proteins can occur when even a small fraction alter their interactions. These efforts open the door to examining the time evolution of three-dimensional membrane structure, which may strongly modulate protein ordering and function in response to damage caused by intense light.
